I mean, so much of this, like the day after, I just thought to myself, if Democrats hadn't been cozying up to big tech for this long, if we see what's happening with Prop 22 in California and how they're now doing the big campaign in New York and other states, but if tech wasn't so connected to the Democratic Party in terms of funding and appointments and the revolving door between different, I mean, would we be in this situation?  I mean, big tech, I think so much of the roots of big tech fall, their libertarian roots.  But the capitalism that has evolved the business model, I should say, has created opportunities for Democrats to be woven into it.  And that's just, it's like pay to play politics.  Not only are they donating to Democrats and Republicans, of course, but they're also bringing actual staffers in who are now back in this administration, but like took some time off and went to Silicon Valley.  I mean, we have to be able to break up with these donors, these companies that are now giving jobs to our staff or the democratic side staffers.  I mean, this is how corruption works.  It's legalized corruption and the results are what we saw.

Yeah, part of the problem is technology companies have for a long time, yeah but technology companies for a long time for decades at this point have like you know had a very um embedded relationship with you know american economy and political system right going back to uh cold war and the role in the military industrial complex or the advent of you know scientific research out of universities.  It's been, they've played a key role in, you know, providing jobs to specific areas of the country and ensuring that surpluses from trade flow back into the country and keep regions that have otherwise been neglected by the state, you know, to still have people employed and still have access to, you know, resources.  But You know, the over time, I think that that bargain has become a Faustian one where these firms now have enough autonomy and sovereignty to dictate the terms on which they'll operate and engage with or follow or abide by the law.  and You know, it's going to require a huge shift, I think, not just in like, you know, the actual laws around these companies, but in the way that the parties or people in the party see their relationship to them.  I think that many still kind of view big tech or technology firms as like you know tech when at its best moments it can help us and can you know let us be better than we might otherwise be can connect us can you know do all these great things.  when you know, the reality is if you take a hard look at it, most technology firms, I mean, they provide some good, you know, consumer facing products, but at great cost to everything else, to the ecology, to people in the global South, the children that they use as laborers or miners to slaves that they use in China or India to, you know, contract workers that they use in the United States.  Is that worth it?  And I think that's also like as big of a pressing question is like, are you fine with allying with firms that will just burn you when they have enough power?
